docs.snippet: There is something women don't do as well as men: sleep. And many respond by taking a pill.
docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S hard to write this sentence: There is something women don't do as well as men. Sleep.

headline.main: Sleep Anxiety Leads Many to the Medicine Cabinet

docs.snippet: There are at least 80 autoimmune diseases, in which the person's immune system directs its fury against the person's own tissues.
docs.lead_paragraph: ROXANNE PEREZ had never really been sick in her life until, at age 27, the roof began falling in. During a Fourth of July weekend at the beach in 2000, she was rushed to an emergency room suffering from convulsions. In the months after, she had blood transfusions and her spleen removed. Then, in 2001, she suffered a heart attack that left her heart permanently weakened. Ms. Perez, who lives in San Antonio, had to give up her job, her home and car and move in with her parents. Now 32, she suffers from frequent fatigue, made worse when she goes out in the sun, and takes 25 different drugs. She said she could never have children.

headline.main: Trying to Shut Off the Body's Friendly Fire

docs.snippet: When you have autoimmune hepatitis, you do not call the disease by its name. You say that your liver is being attacked by your immune system.
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN you have autoimmune hepatitis, you do not call the disease by its name. You say that your liver is being attacked by your immune system. The reason is that a lot of people recoil when they hear the word ''hepatitis,'' assuming that you have been bingeing on alcohol or using intravenous drugs or both.

headline.main: Coping With Illness And Its Treatment

docs.snippet: Higher competitive stakes and issues of self-esteem among girls can lead to a risky shortcut.
docs.lead_paragraph: AS an authority on youth steroid use, Dr. Linn Goldberg is often called when communities feel that flame licking at the doors of their schools. His travel schedule has been especially heavy lately. Last month, Dr. Goldberg came to Connecticut to address 70 high school coaches and athletic directors about a steroid prevention program he helped devise. The session, scheduled at the behest of the governor's office, came two months after a well-publicized incident in which six male athletes from Daniel Hand High School in Madison were arrested for possession of steroid pills that two of the boys bought in Mexico on a family vacation.

headline.main: Schools' Prevention Efforts Aim to Halt Rise of Steroid Use

docs.snippet: The search for rekindled desire shifts from talk to testosterone.
docs.lead_paragraph: SONJA, a stay-at-home mother in Salt Lake City, began to notice a problem after her first daughter was born. ''Before the baby, my libido had gone down a bit from when we were first married and had sex three times a week,'' she said. ''After the baby, my sex drive just died.'' Sonja said she mentioned the loss of libido to her obstetrician, who told her that she was just a busy mom. She reported the problem to her general practitioner, who put her on an antidepressant.

docs.snippet: Areas where women can address their vulnerabilities to heart attacks.
docs.lead_paragraph: WOMEN and men share one characteristic when it comes to heart disease: it's the leading killer of both. But otherwise, much is different -- and not always to women's benefit. For instance, women don't usually experience the classic chest-clutching symptoms. Their first warning sign may be pain in the jaw or neck, fatigue, shortness of breath, a stomachache or nausea, all of which could be associated with another condition. Even the classic chest pain can be misinterpreted. ''A lot of women come to me saying their bras feel too tight,'' said Dr. Maryann McLaughlin, assistant professor of cardiology at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in Manhattan.

headline.main: Paying Attention to That Pain in the Chest: It Could Be Serious

docs.snippet: Move into summer with newer, lighter exercise gear and savory energizers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Jump, run, bend, stretch -- move into summer with newer, lighter exercise gear and savory energizers. HEART WATCH -- Light and multifunctional, the Reebok Women's 30 Heart Rate Monitor is a watch, stopwatch, timer and heart-rate monitor, $85.95; BikeMania.biz. BODY WEAR -- For ultimate performance, CW-X Conditioning Wear, based on kinesiology, the science of human muscular movement, uses a taping system to align the body's muscles and ligaments. Pro tights, $94.95; sport bra, $44.95; cw-x.com. JOURNEY BAG -- One great nylon bag holds a yoga mat, clothes, blocks, straps and a water bottle. In gray, purple or blue, $34.95; huggermugger.com. BOTTLE DIVING SUIT -- Keep up your healthy daily wine consumption with Champagne Veuve Clicquot's Ice Jacket. The yellow neoprene jacket fits a bottle of Veuve Clicquot, zips up the side, has a neck strap and keeps a bottle cold for up to two hours, $10; clicquot.com. The jacket and a bottle of Veuve Cliquot Yellow Label will be in wine shops in July for about $55. SPORT LOOP -- No excuse for losing your sunglasses, keys or MP3 player now with this stretchy neck loop. In two sizes and four colors and costs $18; whitney.org. BOX TO THE TOP -- Everlast's boxing gloves are emblazoned with the logo of the new Muhammad Ali Center in Louisville, Ky., $59.95; alicenter.org. ULTRAFLEET FEET -- For stronger feet, some athletes train barefoot. To simulate that state, the women's Nike Free 5.0 shoe mimics the natural line of the foot as the sole's grooves allow easy movement, $85; nikewomen.com. EVOLVED ENERGY BAR -- PaleyBars, chewy blends of dried fruit and nuts, could be the rainbow at the end of any intense workout. The creation of an Oregon chef and cyclist, the rich, all-natural bars are $24 (plus shipping) for a box of 12; choose one of four flavor combinations or a mixed box; paleybar.com. SUZANNE HAMLIN

headline.main: Sporting Gear And Energizers: Prepping for Summer

docs.snippet: Anxiety disorders affect millions of people in the United States, and women have twice the risk as men.
docs.lead_paragraph: FROM an early age, Grace Mahoney's life was ruled by fear. She recalls having her first panic attack in nursery school, and ''it kind of progressed from there,'' said Ms. Mahoney, 38, of Jackson Hole, Wyo. The attacks would strike randomly, even waking her up. She became so frightened of having an attack that she avoided situations where she didn't have control. ''We would visit my uncle in New York who lived on the 39th floor and my father would walk up all 39 flights with me because I wouldn't get in the elevator,'' she said.

headline.main: Anxiety Disorders: Living on a Thin Line

docs.snippet: Here is the medical consensus  for now  on some of the major health issues facing women.
docs.lead_paragraph: THREE years ago, a woman visiting her doctor to discuss the onset of menopause would most likely leave with a prescription for hormone-replacement therapy and the instruction that she stay on it for the rest of her life. Now, unless her hot flashes or other menopausal problems are severe, the same woman could visit the same doctor and get little more than sympathy.

headline.main: What's a Woman to Believe? The Latest on Shifting Guidelines

docs.snippet: Hashimoto's disease is an autoimmune condition of the thyroid, the gland that regulates the body's energy and metabolism.
docs.lead_paragraph: MY tale of autoimmune diseases reads like an unfortunate series of events, to paraphrase Lemony Snicket. I have Hashimoto's disease, an autoimmune condition of the thyroid, the gland that regulates the body's energy and metabolism. It's a common disease, one in six women will develop it in their lifetime, and it's usually relatively easy to detect, by testing for high levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone, or TSH. But usually isn't always, and it can often go undetected for years and is most commonly diagnosed after age 40.

headline.main: Plenty of Symptoms, But Not Many Clues
